Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Paper-based Microfluidic Viral Diagnostic Device
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the versatile nature of the diagnostic device created to be used in many industries ranging from public health, veterinary medicine, food processing, and water testing. The hand held diagnostic device can be used as a point-of-care detection system in the case of an endemic disease outbreak. Ease of usage and visual color change will help in quick diagnosis as well as prophylactic care. It may also be possible that this will improve detection, treatment and eradication of the target molecule such as in the case of a microbe or toxin leading to quicker patient recovery.

This I-Corps project was based on the concept of using spectrum-shifting ability of gold nanoparticles as detection molecules on a passive paper flow assay. Wax printing technology is used to print channels on filter paper in which an area is treated with lectins, which clump the cellular component of blood and only let plasma flow. The plasma contains the target molecule for which an anti-target molecule protein is adhered onto gold nanoparticles coated at the end of the wax channels. By the concept of a target/anti-target molecule response, the adhered gold nanoparticles attach onto the target molecules and form complexes. This aggregation of causes a shift in the light spectrum leading to a visual color change. Based on the chosen target molecule, gold nanoparticles could be adhered with different types of protein molecules giving an endless possibility the device used for the detection of different target molecules in various industries.

Institution.Name: Tulane University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: ADMINISTRATORS OF THE TULANE EDUCATIONAL FUND, THE

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main overall goal of the project was to assess the market need for a hand held rapid diagnosic for the detection of bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) in cattle. To be able to achieve this goal, interviews were conducted   to examine our business proposition for a diagnostic device within the beef cattle industry. The interviews consisted of professionals in manufacturing, distribution, research and development, and regulation within the beef cattle industry. 

To gather intel to the see the efficacy of the business model, domestic and international travel was done. They interviews and intel collection re A few examples of these locations includes the 2016 Angus Beef Convention, the US Meat Animal Research Center, various cattle operations through the Midwest and Great Plain states, and international operations in India and Singapore. The interviews helped gain data on size of ithe ndustry market, supply chain networks, potential partnerships, number of competitors and their products, and potential of commercialization. 

The customer interviews helped in identifying specific customer archetypes, establishing a supply chain method from manufacturing to distribution, and creating a commercialization plan taking into account customer price-point and accessibility. The interviews also helped in concluding that the BVDV diagnostic would have a better chance of penetrating the American market than in India due to the affordability at the set price point and the presence of far more severe afflictions.

From this grant we were able to positively affirm that our technology is suitable for commercialization and develop a framework for success. With additional parterships, optimizing the detection technology, and further research would help develop this device into a viable solution for the cattle industry.

They interviews and intel collection re A few examples of these locations includes the 2016 Angus Beef Convention, the US Meat Animal Research Center, various cattle operations through the Midwest and Great Plain states, and international operations in India and Singapore. The interviews helped gain data on size of ithe ndustry market, supply chain networks, potential partnerships, number of competitors and their products, and potential of commercialization. From this grant we were able to positively affirm that our technology is suitable for commercialization and develop a framework for success.
